Package com.nrg948.autonomous

package com.nrg948.autonomous
The com.nrg948.autonomous package implements an annotation-based approach for identifying and selecting autonomous commands.

To use the autonomous annotations, add the nrgcommon-processor dependency in your robot program's build.gradle file in addition to the nrgcommon library dependency. 

 
 dependencies {
   implementation "com.nrg948:nrgcommon:${nrgcommon.version}"

   annotationProcessor "com.nrg948:nrgcommon-processor:${nrgcommon.version}"
 }

The AutonomousCommand annotation identifies an autonomous command class. All classes with this annotation must be a subclass of Command and declare the same public constructor taking a list of parameters passed to Autonomous.getChooser(Object...) that are used to access the robot subsystems. This is typically a single parameter of type RobotContainer but may be another type managing access to the subsystems or the list of subsystems themselves. All annotated classes must accept the same types and number of arguments.

The following example shows how to structure and annotate autonomous command classes.

 
 @AutonomousCommand (name = "My Autonomous Command", isDefault = true)
 public class MyAutonomousCommand extends SequentialCommandGroup {
   public MyAutonomousCommand(RobotContainer container) {
     addCommands(
       new DriveToFirstLocation(container.getDrivetrainSubsystem()),
       ...
       )
   }
 }

The AutonomousCommandMethod annotation identifies a public static factory method invoked to create a Command subclass to be run during autonomous. The method takes a list of parameters passed to Autonomous.getChooser(Object...) that are used to access robot subsystems and returns a subclass of Command. This is typically a single parameter of type RobotContainer but may be another type managing access to the subsystems or the list of subsystems themselves. All annotated methods must accept the same types and number of arguments.

The following example shows how to define and annotate an autonomous Command factory method.

 
 public class Autos {
   @AutonomousCommandMethod (name = "My Autonomous Command", isDefault = true)
   public static Command exampleRoutine(RobotContainer container) {
     return Command.sequence(
        new DriveToFirstLocation(container.getDrivetrainSubsystem()),
        ...
     );
   }
 }

Each annotation contains two elements: AutonomousCommand.name() and AutonomousCommand.isDefault(). The name element provides the name to display for the command in user interface elements like SendableChooser. The isDefault element determines which command is the default selection. Only one command class or factory method should be set as the default.

The AutonomousCommandGenerator annotation identifies a public static method invoked to create a collection of elements mapping the name to display in user interface elements like SendableChooser to a Command. The method takes a list of parameters passed to Autonomous.getChooser(Object...) that are used to access robot subsystems and returns a Collection of LabelValue<String, Command> elements. This is typically a single parameter of type RobotContainer but may be another type managing access to the subsystems or the list of subsystems themselves. All annotated methods must accept the same types and number of arguments.

The following example shows how to define and annotate an autonomous Command generator method.

 
 public class Autos {
   @AutonomousCommandGenerator
   public static Collection<LabelValue<String, Command>> exampleGenerator(RobotContainer container) {
     return List.of(
       new LabelValue<String, Command>("First Auto", new FirstAuto(container)),
       new LabelValue<String, Command>("Second Auto", new SecondAuto(container)),
       );
   }
 }

Once all autonomous command classes, factory and/or generator methods have been annotated, the Autonomous.getChooser(Object...) method can be used to create a SendableChooser object enabling interactive selection of the autonomous command from Shuffleboard or SmartDashboard.

The following example shows how to implement interactive autonomous command selection.

 
 public class RobotContainer {
   private DrivetrainSubsystem m_drivetrainSubsystem = new DrivetrainSubsystem();

   private SendableChooser<Command> m_autonomousCommandChooser;

   public RobotContainer() {
     m_autonomousCommandChooser = Autonomous.getChooser(this);

     // Add an "Autonomous" tab to Shuffleboard, create a new layout and add the
     // autonomous command chooser to it.
     Shuffleboard.getTab("Autonomous")
       .getLayout("Autonomous", BuiltInLayouts.kList)
       .withSize(2, 2)
       .add("Command", m_autonomousCommandChooser);
   }

   public DrivetrainSubsystem getDrivetrainSubsystem() {
     return m_drivetrainSubsystem;
   }

   public Command getAutonomousCommand() {
     return m_autonomousCommandChooser.getSelected();
   }
 }
  • Class
    Description
    Autonomous
    A class containing utility methods to support autonomous operation.
    AutonomousCommand
    Annotates a class implementing a subclass of Command to run during autonomous.
    AutonomousCommandGenerator
    Annotates a method that creates a Collection of LabelValue elements mapping the name to display in user interface elements like SendableChooser to a Command.
    AutonomousCommandMethod
    Annotates a method that creates a new subclass of Command to run during autonomous.
